tutorials.name: Basics #1: Getting started!
tutorials.description: Learn the basics: from viewing a project, forking it and a understanding basic concepts of MLReef.
tutorials.epilogue:
## Congratulations!!
You have finished your first tutorial. You should now be able to:

- Explore and fork public projects
- Explore the data in your repository
- Create a new experiment

tasks.title: Explore public ML projects
tasks.instructions: Navigate to the explore tab in your dashboard. MLProjects will host your entire ML life cycle, including your data and pipelines.

tasks.title: Explore the other tabs
tasks.instructions: The tabs **models**, **dataops** and **data visualizations** host functions which can be used in the MLProjects.

tasks.title: Go to the "Basic tutorials" ML project
tasks.instructions: Click this [link](/mlreef/basic-tutorials) or find the project in your dashboard under the **ML projects** / explore tab.

tasks.title: Fork the project
tasks.instructions: Click the forking button. This will copy the entire project to your namespace.

tasks.title: Wait until fork is completed
tasks.instructions: Forking might take some minutes, please be patient!

tasks.title: Explore the data
tasks.instructions:
##### Congratulations! You now own this project.
Explore the data section and discover the files in it.

tasks.title: Open the "Experiments" tab
tasks.instructions: Click the experiment tab. In this section you can start training your models with your data!

tasks.title: Create a new experiment
tasks.instructions: Start a new experiment!

tasks.title: Choose your training data
tasks.instructions: Click the select data button and then choose the **training** folder by selecting it. This will store the path to your dataset - in this case they are cats and dogs images.

tasks.title: Choose the "Resnet50" model
tasks.instructions: Search and *drag and drop* the model named **Resnet50** to your experiment pipeline.

tasks.title: Enter basic parameters
tasks.instructions: The data-input path should already contain the path **train**. In the output field enter **output** - your model artifacts will be stored here. Fill in all the other parameters as described!

tasks.title: Start the experiment
tasks.instructions: If you successfully draged your model and filled all parameters, you should be able to execute your first experiment. Click **execute**.

tasks.title: Choose machine and execute
tasks.instructions: Choose the **GPU machine** from the dropdown and execute your experiment. Your model is now being trained. Press the **show results** button to continue.

tasks.title: Discover your experiment
tasks.instructions: You now should be able to see your new experiment (if not, refresh this page!).

tasks.title: Expand an experiment
tasks.instructions: Click the expand button to see more details about your experiment - such as a running graph, the hyperparameters, what data you used, etc.

tasks.title: Go more in depth!
tasks.instructions: Click on the experiment name to enter a detailed view with more insights and to download the generated model artifacts.

tasks.title: Navigate the tabs
tasks.instructions: Explore the different tabs and finally navigate to the **files** tab. As soon as the experiment has finished, you can download the model and use it!

tutorials.name: Basic #2: Data processing
tutorials.description: Process data and create new datasets for iterative model training.

tasks.title: Go to the data tab
tasks.instructions: Open the [Basic tutorial](/mlreef/basic-tutorials) ML project and navigate to the data tab.

tasks.title: Go to the **Dataops** pipeline
tasks.instructions: Open the dataops pipeline. Here you can pre-processa and create new datasets based on your existing files in your repository.

tasks.title: Select data to process
tasks.instructions: Click the select data button and then choose the **training** folder by selecting it. You process all files contained in this folder, while keeping the folder structure as it is.

tasks.title: Choose the **Add noise** data operation.
tasks.instructions: In the dataops list, search the data processing operation named **add noise** and drag it into your pipeline.

tasks.title: Enter basic parameters
tasks.instructions: The data-input path should already contain the path **train**. In the output any directory name for your output images (e.g. output). Choose from the advanced section any mode you want.

tasks.title: Start the data processing
tasks.instructions: If you successfully draged the datops and filled all parameters, you should be able to execute your dataops pipeline to create a new dataset. Click **execute**.

tasks.title: Choose machine and execute
tasks.instructions: Choose the **CPU machine** from the dropdown and execute the pipeline. Your pipeline should start and cerate a new dataset.

tasks.title: Return to pipeline view
tasks.instructions: Instead of moving forward, let´s create a more complex pipeline. Return to the **dataops* pipeline view.

steps.name: Create a more complex processing pipeline

tasks.title: Select data to pre-process.
tasks.instructions: If needed, click the select data button and then choose the **training** folder by selecting it.

tasks.title: Remove **add noise** operation.
tasks.instructions: We will start with another data operations. Remove the **add noise** operation from the pipeline

tasks.title: Choose the **Augment** data operation.
tasks.instructions: The augment opeartion duplicates and changes your existing data. This is a easy way to create new data from existing data!

tasks.title: Enter augment parameters
tasks.instructions:
Enter the following parameters: 
+ **output**: out1 
+ **iterations**: 3 
+ **rotation-range**: 0 
+ **width-shift-range**: 0 
+ **height-shift-range**: 0 
+ **shear-range**: 0.1 
+ **zoom-range**: 0.2 
+ **horizontal-flip**: true 
+ **vertical-flip**: false.

tasks.title: Choose the **Random Crop** data operation.
tasks.instructions: The next concatenated data opeartion will crop a part of the input images. Drag the operation in position 2 into the pipeline, right after the **augment** operation.

tasks.title: Enter random crop parameters
tasks.instructions:
This time, we will use the output generated from the augment opeartion as input for the next. Type in the **input-path**: out1 (or the output-path name you entered in the augment operation). 
Enter in **output-path** a different folder name (e.g. out2). 
In the advanced section, define the resultion of the croped images (e.g. 100px) for both height and width.

tasks.title: Start the data processing
tasks.instructions:
Now let's create this more complext data processing pipeline. 
Info: You can create any number of concatenations and chaining logics using the input and output paths!.

tasks.title: Choose machine and execute
tasks.instructions: Choose the **CPU machine** from the dropdown and execute the pipeline. Your pipeline should start and cerate a new dataset. Press the **show results** button to continue.

tasks.title: Go to experiment section
tasks.instructions: Click the experiment tab.

tasks.title: Create a new experiment.
tasks.instructions: Click the new experiment button, which is now located at the top right.

tasks.title: Select new dataset
tasks.instructions:
Click the select data button and then select the newly created datset from the dropdown button. 
Info: all datasets are also stored as git branches.

tasks.title: Review the dataset status
tasks.instructions: In the dropdown, you can see the status of the pipelines (green = done, orange = running, red = stopped).

tasks.title: Select new pre-processed files
tasks.instructions: You should be able to see now your newly created output folder (i.e. out 1 and out 2). Select out 2, which contains all newly created images from before.

tasks.title: Finalize with a new model training
tasks.instructions: **Congratulations!** This is how you create and iterate using data pre-precessing. If you want, finish this tutorial with a new experiment!
